documentation.content:
Auction Service for Streamers - pointauc.com

Overview

This service is designed to enhance the interaction between streamers and their audiences by providing a fun and engaging way to make decisions during live streams. Whether it's deciding which game a streamer should play next, which video or movie they should watch with their audience, or running a lottery or contest, this service offers a versatile set of tools to make your streams more interactive and entertaining.

The service features seamless integration with Twitch Channel Points and Donation Alerts, allowing streamers to easily manage incoming donations and channel point redemptions. This saves valuable time and energy, enabling streamers to focus on what they do best—entertaining their audience!

Integrations

The Pointauc supports the following integrations to enhance your streaming experience:

  • Twitch Channel Points:

    Allows viewers to use their channel points to participate in auctions, lotteries, and other activities directly through Twitch.

  • Donation Alerts:

    Integrates with Donation Alerts to manage monetary donations, which can be used in place of or alongside channel points in auctions and contests.

  • DonatePay (another donation service)

Features

1. Game & Content Auctions

  • Streamers can create auctions where viewers bid using channel points or donations to decide which game should be played next or which content should be watched during the stream or any other activity.

2. Lotteries & Contests

  • Run exciting lotteries or contests where viewers can participate using their channel points or donations. Multiple formats are available, including random draw, highest bid, or entry-based selection.

3. Decision-Making Tools

  • Choose from a variety of interactive decision-making tools to select winners or make choices:
    • Wheel of Fortune: Spin a wheel to randomly select a winner or outcome.
    • Dropout Wheel: Eliminate options gradually until only one remains.
    • Battle Royale: A competitive elimination-style game where participants are gradually removed until the final winner is determined.

4. Real-Time Updates

  • Real-time tracking and updates ensure that viewers and streamers are always in sync with the latest bids.

5. Customizable Settings

  • Streamers can personalize the website's appearance, automate timer rules, and add custom enhancements like Marbles on Stream Auction and more. Additionally, the service supports automatic bid creation using channel points, simplifying a work for the streamer.

Suggestions and bug reports

You can create an issue if you want to suggest something or tell about a bug.

instructions.title: Overlays Setup Guide
instructions.helpButtonHint: You can reopen these instructions anytime by clicking the help button (?) near the page title at the top of the screen.
instructions.listPageDescription: On the main overlays page, you'll see all your created overlays. Click the "New Overlay" button to create a new one.
instructions.createOverlayDescription: Select the type of overlay you want to create: Auction (shows your auction bids and timer) or Wheel (displays the spinning wheel). Each overlay is created with sensible defaults that you can customize later.
instructions.editPageDescription: After creating an overlay, you'll be taken to the editor page with two main sections:
instructions.settingsPanelDescription: Configure overlay-specific options like which elements to display, background transparency, canvas resolution, and more.
instructions.previewPanelDescription: Adjust the overlay position and size by dragging and resizing. Changes are saved automatically and will be reflected in OBS.
instructions.detailsContent1: After saving changes, your active overlay will be updated automatically.
instructions.detailsContent2: Canvas Resolution should match your streaming resolution (typically 1920x1080 for 1080p or 1280x720 for 720p).
instructions.detailsContent3: You can create multiple overlays with different settings for different scenes in your streaming software.
instructions.obsWarning: Stretch the overlay to the entire screen and do not move it. All positioning is controlled through the preview panel on the website.
instructions.obsStep1Description: On the overlay edit page, find the "OBS Link" section and click "Copy Link" to copy your unique overlay URL.
instructions.obsStep2Title: Step 2: Add Browser Source in OBS
instructions.obsStep2Description: In OBS, right-click in your Sources panel, select "Add" → "Browser", and paste the overlay URL.
instructions.obsSettingsDescription: Use these settings when adding the Browser source:
instructions.refreshWhenActive: Refresh browser when scene becomes active
instructions.advancedTip1: Match the Width and Height in OBS to your Canvas Resolution setting on the website for pixel-perfect alignment.
instructions.advancedTip2: If the overlay doesn't appear immediately, make sure you have the auction or wheel page open on the website to initialize the data.
instructions.finalStepDescription: Your overlay is now set up! Any changes you make on the website (bids, settings, positioning) will automatically update in OBS.

intro.title: How Winner Selection Works
intro.description: The random number that determines the wheel winner can be generated in different ways. Each option has its own advantages and trade-offs. Read about each option to understand which one works best for you.
intro.tldrNote: Each option includes a TLDR and Pros/Cons sections, so you don't have to read all details.
intro.choosePrompt: Choose a randomness source to learn more:
intro.standardDescription: Fast and simple, works for most cases

localBasic.tldrText: Use this when your audience trusts you and you don't mind using pseudo-random generation.
localBasic.explanation: This method uses your browser's built-in cryptographic random number generator (crypto.getRandomValues). While technically pseudo-random, it's sufficiently random for this application type and the difference between pseudo-random and true random is negligible.
localBasic.verificationText: The code is open-source and anyone can verify that this exact code is deployed on the website.

randomOrg.tldrText: Use this if you need true randomness and want to emphasize fairness but don't need cryptographic proof.
randomOrg.whatIsItText: Random.org is a trusted third-party service that generates true random numbers based on atmospheric noise.
randomOrg.howItGenerates: Learn more about <1>how Random.org generates randomness</1>.
randomOrg.implementationText: The website makes an API call to Random.org during the spin to get a random number.
randomOrg.con2: Viewers must still trust the streamer
randomOrg.con3: True randomness is often overrated for this use case

randomOrgSigned.tldrText: Use this when you need maximum security and transparency. Anyone can independently verify that neither the streamer nor the website could affect the outcome.
randomOrgSigned.shortDescription2: All parties can see the ticket serial number before the spin and accept that this ticket will decide the winner.
randomOrgSigned.shortDescription3: During the spin random.org assign a random number to this ticket.
randomOrgSigned.shortDescription4: Anyone can verify which number was generated for this ticket and the exact time when this ticket was revealed.
randomOrgSigned.analogyIntro: Imagine you're buying a scratch-off lottery ticket. Here's how it works:
randomOrgSigned.analogyStep1: A trusted lottery company produces tickets in their secure factory. Each ticket has a unique serial number and a hidden prize value covered by a special coating. The company keeps a record of every ticket they've created, including when it was made and what prize it contains.
randomOrgSigned.analogyStep2: These tickets are shipped to retail stores. Each store receives a batch of tickets, still sealed with their prizes hidden. The store owners can sell the tickets but have no way to know which tickets are winners without scratching them.
randomOrgSigned.analogyStep3: You walk into your local convenience store and buy a ticket. The cashier hands you a ticket with its prize completely covered - neither you nor the cashier knows what's underneath.
randomOrgSigned.analogyStep4Title: Scratching Off the Coating (Revealing the Random Number)
randomOrgSigned.analogyStep4: Later that day, you scratch off the coating to reveal your prize. At this moment, you see the random value for the first time. The ticket's serial number, the prize value, and special security features are now all visible.
randomOrgSigned.analogyStep5: If someone doubts the ticket authenticity, you can take the ticket back to any lottery office. They'll scan the serial number and confirm: (1) The ticket is genuine and was produced by them, (2) It was created before you purchased it, (3) The prize value matches their records, (4) The security features prove it hasn't been tampered with. You can even show video footage of yourself scratching it to prove when it was revealed.
randomOrgSigned.analogyConclusion: In the digital world, Random.org can confirm the exact time when the random number was scratched and revealed.
randomOrgSigned.technicalDetailsText: For a complete technical explanation of how signed random numbers work and how to verify them independently, visit the verification instructions page.
randomOrgSigned.pro1: Winner outcome can be verified by any viewer or streamer
randomOrgSigned.con1: Limited to 6 spins per day (API costs money)

verification.title: Ticket Verification Instructions
verification.introduction: This page explains how the signed random number generation system works and how anyone can independently verify that the winner selection was fair and unbiased.

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites Required for Ticket Validation
prerequisites.showParticipants: Streamer showed the full list of participants before the spin
prerequisites.showTicket: Streamer showed Random.org ticket card before the spin

verification.analogyDescription: Click to expand a real-world analogy that explains how signed randomness works in simple terms.
verification.flowTitle: How the Signed Random Flow Works
verification.flowDescription: The signed random system uses a ticketed approach similar to scratch-off lottery tickets:

flow.step1: Streamer selects 'Random.org+ (Verifiable)' as the RNG method
flow.step2: The system requests an unrevealed ticket from Random.org
flow.step3: Streamer shows ticket details to everyone and starts the wheel spin (ticket ID is partially visible to prevent viewers from guessing the winner before the spin is finished)
flow.step4: Random.org generates the random number and signs it specifically for this ticket
flow.step5: The random number determines the winner, and all data is recorded for verification, the full ticket data is displayed on the screen

verification.verificationStepsIntro: Anyone can verify the fairness of the winner selection by checking two things:
verification.step1Description: Verify that the random number was legitimately generated by Random.org before the spin:
verification.step1List2: Enter the ticket data and the signature (available on the revealed ticket page)
verification.step1List3: Random.org will confirm if the signature is valid
verification.step1List4: Cross-reference the timestamps and ticket ID with the stream VOD to ensure that this is the same ticket that was present on the screen before the spin
verification.step2Description: Verify that the winner was correctly selected from the random number:
verification.step2Description2: The main rule is that the same pair of random number and participants list should always produce the same winner regardless of user device or time of the day
verification.algorithmStep1: Participants are sorted by lot amount (ascending), then by name (alphabetically)
verification.algorithmStep2: The random number [0-1) is multiplied by the total amount (threshold)
verification.algorithmStep3: The algorithm walks through participants, subtracting their amounts, until the threshold reached <= 0 - that participant is the winner
verification.algorithmSource: View the exact algorithm in the <1>source code on GitHub</1>
verification.step2List1: Verify the participant list from the ticket matches what was shown on stream
verification.step2List2: Manually calculate the winner using the random number and algorithm
verification.step2List3: Confirm the recorded winner matches your calculation
verification.recordStructureDescription: Each revealed ticket page displays the following information:

recordField.ticketIdDescription: Unique identifier from Random.org for this ticket
recordField.timestampsDescription: Creation time (when ticket was requested) and reveal time (when the random number was generated)
recordField.randomNumberDescription: The actual random value [0-1) used to determine the winner
recordField.participantsDescription: Complete list of all participants with their lot amounts, sorted according to the algorithm
recordField.signatureDescription: Cryptographic signature from Random.org that proves authenticity

verification.conclusion: By verifying both the random number generation and the winner selection algorithm, you can be confident that the outcome was fair and that neither the streamer nor the website could have influenced the result.
verification.tbdDescription: This section will be expanded with additional information.
verification.tbdItem1: Describing potential attack vectors and how to catch them
